Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Integrated Multi-functional Solar Panel Antenna Array

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
GOALI: Integrated Multi-functional Solar Panel Antenna Array

The objective of this research is to explore reconfigurable phased array antennas that are directly integrated with solar cells to form multi-functional panels. The approach is to integrate smart combinations of transparent mesh antennas and slot antennas on or around solar cells, and then to creatively excite the antennas to achieve multiple diversity.

Intellectual Merit: This research solves one of the most important problems in space exploration by integrating electromagnetics with solar cells. The project addresses fundamentals of optimal antenna elements with minimal impact on solar cells, integration of active electronics with antennas on solar panels, and reconfigurablility. The development will yield active phased reconfigurable antenna array integrated on solar panels for very high data rate communication, transmitting energy harvested from space, and for low cost space mission by re-using one panel for multiple flights. None of those advantages can be achieved by traditional antennas.

Broader Impacts: Besides satellite applications, the proposed integration technique can be employed to form self-powered ground receivers. Research outcomes can be easily adapted to integration of antennas with composite surfaces such as wings of unmanned aerial vehicle for various applications. On the education side, this collaborative effort with industry will create exciting hands-on projects in undergraduate classrooms, senior designs, and summer internship opportunities. The industry partner will take the leadership in commercializing the proposed technology from laboratory to ready-to-implement level, which will directly impact urban communication, renewable energy research, and space weather monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to design array antennas that are directly integrated with solar cells to form multi-functional panels. The approach is to integrate combinations of transparent mesh antennas on top of solar cells or slot antennas around them. This research solves a bottle-neck problem in space exploration by providing the most effective yet low cost communication systems for a CubeSat, a very small modular satellite that is blooming in space studies.

The project has accomplished the following tasks.

(1)   Quantification of the interaction between the off-the-shelf triple junction space solar cells on the antennas integrated on top. The assessment is valid for antenna operating from 1 GHz to 40 GHz. This study also quantifies the shadow cast by the antenna on the solar cell. The outcome of the assessment is a design guide on integrating planar antenna on top of solar cells. The outcome also provides a guideline to co-design both antenna and solar cell to achieve the maximum efficiency for both. The results from this assessment are summarized in published conference and journal papers.

(2)   Design of a high-gain highly transparent reflectarray antenna integrated on top of solar panel. During the course of the project, the PI’s group survey different types of array antenna and concluded that the reflectarray would be more effective than the phased array. This is because of the gain loss duo to the solar cell (assessment from the previous task). Such a loss is additive in phased array configuration, whereas in reflectarray it can be reduced. Consequently, several reflectarrays that may fit larger CubeSats were examined and design guideline on the most effective geometry has been provided.

(3)   Reconfigurable antennas integrated with solar panel. A study in designing a realistic polarization reconfigurable slot antenna that can be integrated with solar cells was performed and the outcome was presented in a conference proceeding.

(4)   As an extra study that was not included in the original proposal, the project team also studied and demonstrated one of the first conformal UHF slot antenna wrapped around a CubeSat. The antenna is circularly polarized and there is no mechanical deployment is needed.

(5)   The project provided projects for undergraduate senior designs. At least two students conducted their design projects under PI’s supervision funded by this grant. In particular, one of them designed and integrated a directional antenna on a commercial solar panel. The design is to provide a self-powered, high gain (long range) communication to a handset in an outdoor setting. A picture from this senior design has been included.

This GOALI project generated 4 published peer reviewed conference papers, 1 peer reviewed journal paper, and 4 accepted conference papers.

This project also established further ties of the PI with industry, which the PI has been successfully able to extend to other collaborations such as a project funded by NASA.
